newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan says may cut tariff on pork imports.
newsitem.headline: Japan says may cut tariff on pork imports.

text.p: Japan will cut an import tariff on foreign pork if domestic pork prices keep rising following Taiwan's ban on pork exports, an Agriculture Ministry official said on Thursday.
Japan introduced the tariff last July.
"If domestic pork prices keep rising and damage local consumers' interests, we may have to cut import tariff rates," Vice Agriculture Minister Masayuki Takahashi told Reuters.
Japan imposed an emergency tariff on pork imports last July, increasing average import prices by 24 percent.

The measure, taken to protect local producers from an influx of imports, is scheduled to expire at the end of June. Japan is permitted under GATT rules to impose emergency tariffs on pork imports if they exceed certain levels.
Domestic pork prices have risen sharply since Japan banned imports of pork from Taiwan late last month due to an outbreak of foot and mouth disease there.
Pork carcasses in Tokyo traded at 598 yen per kg on Wednesday, sharply up from an average 481 yen in March and 461 yen in February.
"We're carefully monitoring price fluctuations in the local pork market. But at this stage I can't tell when the rates will be cut," Takahashi said.

Finance Ministry data shows that Japan imported 653,176 tonnes of pork in 1996, of which 266,225 tonnes or 40.7 percent came from Taiwan. Other pork suppliers to Japan are the United States, Canada and the European Union.
